description.plain:
“ceilings” is the eighth track on Lizzy McAlpine’s second album, five seconds flat. The track was performed previous to the album’s release during her tour with English musician dodie, where Lizzy served as the opening act.

Lyrically, the song finds the singer-songwriter daydreaming about someone at the end of a date. In an interview for People, McAlpine revealed “ceilings” is a nostalgic reminiscence of a past relationship.

I had just ended things with someone and then went to London for three months to … not escape that [relationship], but also, kind of, do that. And this song is basically just a reflection on that relationship — but not being in it anymore.

body.plain:
“ceilings” is the eighth track on Lizzy McAlpine’s second album, five seconds flat. The track was performed previous to the album’s release during her tour with English musician dodie, where Lizzy served as the opening act.

Lyrically, the song finds the singer-songwriter daydreaming about someone at the end of a date. In an interview for People, McAlpine revealed “ceilings” is a nostalgic reminiscence of a past relationship.

I had just ended things with someone and then went to London for three months to … not escape that [relationship], but also, kind of, do that. And this song is basically just a reflection on that relationship — but not being in it anymore.

songs.full_title: Lizzy McAlpine - ceilings (Traducción al Español) by Genius Traducciones al Español
songs.title: Lizzy McAlpine - ceilings (Traducción al Español)

annotations:
And it feels like the end of a movie I’ve seen before
 Before
Could be a reference to The Wizard of Oz, which ended with it all being a dream

But it’s over
 Then you’re driving me home
 And it kinda comes out as I get up to go

“But it’s over,” refers to the fact that she’s starting to exit this fantasy. The next two lines may mean that because she knew it was almost over, she had to get to the “good part” before it ended.

As stated previously, she wanted to say she loves them, and now, she finally does.
Lovely to sit between comfort and chaos

She finds a thrill in knowing that at any moment, she could tell them she loves them, as shown in “hate to be lame.” She knows that if she tells them this, it’s almost certain that the mood of the moment would change, but at the moment they’re content.
Lovely to be rained on with you

The last lyric, saying that her shoes are wet, shows that something that would normally be considered negative is happening. However, this lyric shows that the bad thing doesn’t matter to her. She’s fine with it all because it’s nice to be with the other person.

And I don’t wanna leave
 But I have to go

At first listen, we believe this means she has a commitment to attend to and she does not want to leave because she is enjoying the moment with someone she loves. However, we later realize that it is because her fantasy dream is ending and she cannot do anything to stop it.
Then you’re driving me home

Again, an abrupt change of setting from being rained on to being driven home. Few details about story progression, interactions with partner or emotions while in ‘love.’ She is only dreaming about very common romantic scenes (being rained on with someone, being driven home by partner as the sun sets) often portrayed in media.
It’s kinda cute but it’s so short

This is line 4 repeated but changed from “you’re” to “it’s”, suggesting the ‘cute’ experience is coming from the exciting feeling of being in love, rather than the actual person. This is because it is a dream. This could mean that the writer has not really been in love as she cannot even describe this partner in detail let alone draw comparisons to anyone else in her life.

These ideas are further reinforced by the line “it’s so short.” Not only because a dream is so short but also there is not much to dream about as she has not been in love. She only knows how it is portrayed in movies, as suggested in the final line of the chorus.

Reinforcing ‘kinda’ gives us certainty about her lack of certainty that the moment she is sharing with her partner is genuine.

You’re kinda cute but it’s raining harder
 My shoes are now full of water

A normal phenomenon ‘rain’ and her drenched shoes directs attention away from the person she is supposedly infatuated with. This is achieved through a contrast of details and musically through pauses. “You’re kinda cute” is also sang faster than the following phrases. This suggests she is not in love as the commonplace setting is paid more attention than the ‘partner’. These thoughts are more reflective of her own thoughts when she is in the rain alone. Perhaps influenced by the actual weather in reality while she is dreaming.

The change in setting from ‘ceilings’ to her being outside, implied from her shoes being full of water, also hints her transition to her dream.

Ceilings, plaster
 Can’t you just make it move faster?

Poetry. In nine words, McAlpine articulates where eyes fall during a fevered fantasy and the yearning to reach the end of the lucid daydream where completion is found. How better to describe delusion than through pleading with oneself to dig to the dopamine?

You’re kinda cute and I would say all of this
 But I don’t wanna ruin the moment

These lines describe indecisiveness to tell this person that you like them. It is a theme also explored in “hate to be lame:

It’s always on the tip of my tongue
But I stop myself from sayin' it
Tell myself it’s not the right time or something dumb

description.plain:
Released as a single following Lizzy McAlpine’s 2021 EP, When The World Stopped Moving, “doomsday” is a departure — the inevitability of death and its acceptance as part of life. In other words, the end of a love for which Lizzy is planning her own funeral and that of a person she once loved.

The song was released alongside a Gus Black directed music video, for which Lizzy wrote the script.

song.title: ​doomsday

album.full_title: five seconds flat by Lizzy McAlpine
album.name: five seconds flat

body.plain:
Released as a single following Lizzy McAlpine’s 2021 EP, When The World Stopped Moving, “doomsday” is a departure — the inevitability of death and its acceptance as part of life. In other words, the end of a love for which Lizzy is planning her own funeral and that of a person she once loved.

The song was released alongside a Gus Black directed music video, for which Lizzy wrote the script.

songs.full_title: Lizzy McAlpine - doomsday (Traducción al Español) by Genius Traducciones al Español
songs.title: Lizzy McAlpine - doomsday (Traducción al Español)

annotations: I’ll book the marching band to play as you speak

My interpretation of this line is that “marching band” has connotations of victory and patriotism.

It suggests that her ex would feel a sense of victory when he initiates the breakup (“You’re such a narcissist, you’ll probably do it next week”). He sees the two of them as rivals instead of them being together, and it’s a matter of who breaks up first, because for him, it would show his control over her.

The patriotism aspect of it probably just shows that he is only completely devoted to himself and he’s a narcissist.

Pull the plug, make it painless
 I don’t want a violent end
 Don’t say that you’ll always love me
 ’Cause you know I’d bleed myself dry for you
 Over and over again

Saying “I don’t want a violent end,” and then saying “I’d bleed myself dry for you over and over again,” is seemingly contradictory.

This may show that again, Lizzy has no control over when these breakups may happen, but she willingly goes through them all for love.

Since she says “Over and over again,” She may be talking about an on and off relationship.
No friends and family allowed
instead of using “friends or family” she deliberates with “and”. Like the start of a priest’s wedding script “friends and family, we are gathered here today”. Or in this instance a eulogy.

I’ll feel like throwin’ up
 You’ll sit and stare like a goddamn machine

The narrator believes that when she gets broken up with, she will feel sick. This intense feeling is furthered in other lyrics when McAlpine uses a “show, don’t tell” method to compare the feeling to dying and impending doom.

The narrator also believes that when she gets broken up with, her lover will not care for her feelings after the fact. This is reflected in later lines when she describes her lover as a narssacist.

Only my murderer, you
 And the priest who told you to go to Hell

The wording of this line is interesting-despite the rest of this song portraying the subject as the cause of Lizzy’s metaphorical death, this line separates ‘you’ from ‘my murderer’.
This implies that although Lizzy is aware of the pain caused by her ex, she still views him as separate from the person that ended the relationship and ‘killed her’.

I’d like to plan out my part in this
 But you’re such a narcissist

She wants to have a say in when the relationship ends. However, she knows that her partner, as controlling as he is, would do it before she gets the chance to communicate, taking away her power of choice.

(Also such a good rhyme.)
I’ll hang on ’til the chaos is through
At this moment in the song, you can hear the sound of bones suddenly cracking, which means that her optimism in her lover was what ended up metaphorically killing her.
I booked the marching band to play as you speak

There could be two meanings to this:


She wants them to be serenaded during her funeral. The intention is pure and melodic
She wants the marching band (which is usually quite loud) to play over the person’s voice so no one can hear them talk, it’s passive agression.

Pull the plug in September
 I don’t wanna die in June

Lizzy explained on her Instagram that the first two lines sprouted from a TikTok she saw. In response to a fan’s question about the line, she explained:


Okay so fun fact, I saw a TikTok back in March about how if you were to die in the month of June, then in your next life, you’d be a Gemini. And the girl in the TikTok was like, ‘Oh hell nah, don’t let me become a Gemini in my next life please. Please don’t let me die in June.’ And I was like, ‘Wait, that’s kind of a sick concept, so I took it and turned it into the first two lines of “doomsday.”

And then I connected it to feeling like your relationship is doomed and trying & failing to have any sort of control over when it ends. But yeah, the first two lines were in fact inspired by a TikTok about not wanting to become a Gemini in your next life LMAO

I’d have liked to plan out my part in this
 But you’re such a narcissist
 That you did it on Halloween

From the very first lines, Lizzy asks her partner to wait longer, from June to September, before ending their relationship. While she first thought he would end it quickly, the breakup finally took place on Halloween, October 31st. This underscores the time Lizzy spent in the relationship, knowing she was doomed to failure not wanting to be the one to pull the plug. But also that Lizzy’s ex couldn’t have waited for Halloween to be over: her fun had to be ruined.

The singer notably refers to Halloween in the context of this former boyfriend in the following tweet:
https://twitter.com/LizzyMcAlpine/status/1454253418093027328

description.plain:
“hate to be lame” is the eleventh track off Lizzy McAlpine’s sophomore album, five seconds flat, in which she calls on the artist FINNEAS to help contextualize the insecurities and fears during a love relationship.

Love songs are very common but “hate to be lame” not only captures what it feels like to be about to say “I love you,” it also shows the anxiety that comes with those words. Lizzy is afraid of saying too much and pushing the other person away, while also feeling like she’s not saying enough and trying to force herself to say something even if she doesn’t mean it, just so she doesn’t lose the person.

As for the collaboration, Lizzy sent an Instagram DM to FINNEAS on January 20, 2021, asking if he would want to be on this song with her. He responded with a simple: “YES DUDE.”

annotations:
Don’t really trust what’s on the internet
 But maybe just this once

Her saying this shows that normally she has doubts about whether things on the internet are correct, but this time she feels inclined to listen to what it says. This may show that inside, she really does want to believe that she is falling in love.
It’s always on the tip of my tongue

“On the tip of my tongue,” in this case, is used to indicate that she is about to utter a comment but thinks better of it. This is how the phrase is often used.

Within the context of the rest of the song, It can be inferred that what she’s about to say is that she might love him.

This phrase is being used like a hook in  an essay, something to draw the listeners in.

Do I love him? Do I need him?
 Do I want him? Do I care enough to say
 That I love him, that I need him?
 ’Cause I don’t but I want to feel okay
 If I love him, if I need him
 Maybe that will make him stay
 If I lie, will I still feel this way?

Here, the female singer is going back in forth with her emotions on whether or not she actually loves him or if she loves the idea of him.

She wants to need and love him but also believes she’s lying to herself about it. Likewise, if she keeps lying to herself (if it is a lie, after all) he won’t leave and the idea of having someone stay by her side is more important than sorting out her feelings.
Outro:

The Outro is Lizzy McAlpine and Philip Etherington talking on the first day they met, right before recording Apple Pie, a song from Lizzy McAlpine’s debut album, Give Me A Minute, as shared by her Instagram story on 05/04/22
If I could rewind, would there be some butterfly effect?

“butterfly effect” means that small changes in initial conditions can lead to large-scale and unpredictable variation in the future, like the flapping of a butterfly’s wings could cause a hurricane.

In the song, FINNEAS sings about the hope of finding the original point of when their relationship started so he could ruin it and make they never ever  get to met each other.

description.plain: Lizzy McAlpine and her male counterpart on “reckless driving”, Ben Kessler describe driving with a loved one. Lizzy talks about her experience while driving with your significant other in the passenger seat. She states that she drives carefully because she cares about her male counterpart and wants to maintain a safety for both of them to continue spending time together. Kessler describes his driving style as reckless, because at the end of the day, it only matters that they are together and he wants to be present in every moment. The song overall describes how two partners express their love in different ways that are polar opposite from each other, but the love is there regardless

translation_songs.title: Lizzy McAlpin - reckless driving (Traducción al Español)

annotations: That I feel safe when you sit shotgun

Continuing the metaphor of being in a car, this line indicates that he wants to be in a relationship with McAlpine instead of going through life by himself or with anyone else. This line can also be interpreted literally. In that case, it means that he finds comfort in her cautiousness and thinks they’re a good fit together because she can keep him under control, making the car ride safer.

’Cause I don’t love you like that
 (’Cause I love you like that)

The opposites attracting theme is repeated multiple times in the song.

Reckless driver vs. Careful driver.
Loves too much vs. Doesn’t love enough.

This chorus shows the opposing feelings of both singers but yet they still simultaneously match with one another showing again the theme of opposites attracting.

And now we’re at one eighty
 And I can finally see

Some clever wordplay is used here, as the term “one-eighty” means two things: One-hundred-eighty miles per hour, but also one-hundred-eighty degrees. The two characters are at a turning point in their relationship, where one is not willing to go any further and the other is desperately trying to hold on.
I’m a careful driver

Lizzy comparing herself to a careful driver is a metaphor for her role in the relationship. She’s cautious, going slowly to avoid pushing the other person too far. She’s scared that she’ll do something that’ll scare the other person away and break them up.
[Chorus: Lizzy McAlpine, Ben Kessler]

In this chorus the two different voices sing contrasting lines, which gives the idea that they are arguing with each other in the car. This is supported by how the song (or argument) cuts off abruptly at the end.

I’m a careful driver
 (I’m a reckless driver)

The contrast between being a careful driver and a reckless driver mirrors the contrast between someone who is willing to fall in love against someone who is more withdrawn. Here it seems Lizzy’s character is more reluctant to fall and is trying to set a boundary with Ben’s, whereas Ben’s character is falling and he is falling fast. He is reckless in love whereas Lizzy is more careful.
And one day it will kill us if I—
The song suddenly cuts off in the middle of a sentence to imply to the listener that the reckless driving killed them both in a car accident.

annotations:
I wanna watch a TV show together
 And when we’re under the weather we can watch it in bed
 I wanna go out on the weekends
 I wanna dress up just to get undressed
just wanna be able to share this

Oh, and to tell you is too scary
 So I’ll just say something else
 And I wish that you could hear me
 When I talk to myself

So in this it’s showing how she wants to confess her feelings for her friend but is scared of ruining a good friendship.
She wants her friend to be able to hear her thoughts and her inner dialogue of her confessing said feelings but linking back to it she is still really scared

I wanna eat pancakes for dinner
 I wanna get stuck in your head
 I wanna watch a TV show together
 And when we’re under the weather we can watch it in bed
 I wanna go out on the weekends

Everything here is a cute, pleasant, and wonderful part of a good relationship. Doing something goofy like eating pancakes at night, watching shows together, sleeping in the same bed… these are all clearly hallmarks of a good relationship, and yet she never explicitly states that she wants a relationship with the subject of the song. She uses these as hints of the kind of love she wants to experience with the subject.

So what the hell do I have to lose?
 If I just tell you

Confessing your love to a friend is stressful and scary. The pre-chorus section seems to be the singer “hyping herself up” to tell this person how she feels. The “what the hell do I have to lose” isn’t directed at the song’s subject, but rather at the singer herself, as she gives herself the courage to finally speak up. This dynamic of fear and courage is also well represented in the pause between the pre-chorus and the chorus, which can be seen as the singer taking a deep breath before she finally says what’s on her mind.

Don’t wanna be forward
 Don’t wanna cross a line
 But if I were to crash in this plane tonight
 I’d want you to know this

As anyone who has ever been in love with a friend knows, there’s a constant urge to confess your love as well as a fear of ruining the friendship. This internal conflict is clearly spelled out here: the singer clearly wants the subject of the song to know how she feels, but she starts verses 1, 2, and 3 with a reason /not/ to tell them how she feels. The way I see it, the plane crash isn’t exactly a realistic fear, but the singer looking for a reason to confess. She wants so badly to say how she feels, so she “invents” a reason (that being how she may never make it home) and uses it as an excuse to admit how she feels, even though the reason isn’t exactly likely. She wants to tell this person how she feels but needs one last “kick” in order to do so.

Or maybe I won’t ever say what’s in my head
 No, I won’t have to say anything
 You’ll say it instead
saying that she has waited too long till the point where the person confesses to her that they like someone else or the “friendzone”
I wanna eat pancakes for dinner

eating pancakes for dinner is an odd thing because pancakes are seen as an breakfast food more than a dinner dish. the artist might be saying that she wants to “eat pancakes for dinner” as in try something new. something different than like “eating pancakes for breakfast” which is perceived as ordinary.
But this plane might not land safely

the plane can represent the conversation going into confessing feelings and the artist doubting herself  by saying the plane “might not land safely” meaning that the conversation will not go well and will lead to bad endings.
I wanna dress up just to get undressed
Reference to hooking up/dressing up for a date and then coming back and hooking up

description.plain:
erase me is an upbeat pop song that joins doomsday in marking a sharp change in Lizzy’s sound as she shifts towards a more highly-produced, pop-focused style and away from her better-known more intimate style that primarily features guitar and Lizzy’s vocals.

Understated yet rich harmonies unmistakably provided by none other than Jacob Collier add beautiful texture to the song, along with a strong drum track and an explosive ending. This collaboration also hints at a possible Lizzy feature on Collier’s fourth Djesse album.

body.plain:
erase me is an upbeat pop song that joins doomsday in marking a sharp change in Lizzy’s sound as she shifts towards a more highly-produced, pop-focused style and away from her better-known more intimate style that primarily features guitar and Lizzy’s vocals.

Understated yet rich harmonies unmistakably provided by none other than Jacob Collier add beautiful texture to the song, along with a strong drum track and an explosive ending. This collaboration also hints at a possible Lizzy feature on Collier’s fourth Djesse album.

songs.title_with_featured: Lizzy McAlpine - erase Me (Traducción al Español)

translation_songs.title: Lizzy McAlpine - erase Me (Traducción al Español)

annotations: Skeletons crawl on the ceiling, they know

“Skeletons” as in discreditable or embarrassing facts that Lizzy wishes to keep secret.
Her skeletons that she tries to hide are “crawling on the ceiling”, unseen for those who aren’t looking for them, but seeing everything.

Race you to the end (Ohh-woah)
 My innocence waits like it desperately knows

She uses this ‘race’ as a metaphor for getting over the relationship. Turning it into a race. She is also self aware that if she chooses to not let go of the relationship it will end up as a car crash tying back to “reckless driving”
And you’re fadin’ (Fadin’), but he feels like you in between
The memory of her past relationship is slowly fading, but is brought back from this encounter with a new person, reminding her of intimate times with her previous ex
That I’ll crash if I don’t let you go (Go)
This stanza introduces the car crash/racing thread that is referenced a few times throughout the album. It is most notably explored in reckless driving and orange show speedway.

I don’t know his name, but I still taste the rum (Rum, rum, rum, rum)
 Nothing there but skin

It’s unlikely she had any real feelings for her fling from the night before, if she needed alcohol it to happen. The fact she remembers the drink they shared, better than his own name, speaks just how insincere she was about spending the night with him.

When she, now awake, looks over at him asleep beside her, she sees ‘nothing but skin’ – a person she used in order to escape her own misery.
That him and his aftershave hit like a drug

Unlike her ex-lover, she never had any real feelings for her fling from the night before. Instead, she relied on any little excuse to get down with him (e.g. the nice smell of their aftershave), so that she can forget about the gaping hole in her heart.

She uses ‘drug’ to describe his appeal, once again confirming that last night’s romance was the kind driven by substances, and not passion.

Don’t answer me, I’m callin’ just to hear you scream
 And you’re fadin’, but he feels like you in between
 I’ve said too much, in and out of wantin’ us
 Now you’re fadin’ and I wonder who will erase me?
 Who will erase me? Mmm

She is slowly forgetting her former lover, and is using other men to fill the lack left by him. “Who will erase me?” is her thinking that one of these men might actually replace him and allow her to fully let go in her mind.

Alternatively, she may be wondering if he is going through a similar process of letting go, and is waiting for someone who will erase his memory of her.

I think Lizzy is probably aware of both interpretations, and she chooses to lean into the ambiguity of the phrase “erase me”.

description.plain:
An upbeat and reminiscing song, “​all my ghosts” was released as a single on Lizzy McAlpine’s album, five seconds flat. The song and music video were released together, with the video featuring a cameo from Jacob Collier.

The song is about being free from past experiences and coming to terms with them. Lizzy based the song on real life. She said in the behind-the-scenes video:

It’s all based on real experiences, all the lyrics [are] things that I did.

annotations:
’Cause I hate all of my habits
 But I happen to love you
 I hope that’s true

I personally think this is a reference to hate to be lame, as in the bridge, she says:

“Do I love him? Do I need him?
Do I want him? Do I care enough to say
That I love him, that I need him?
‘Cause I don’t but I wanna feel okay
If I love him, if I need him
Maybe that will make him stay
If I lie, will I still feel this way?”

All of the lyrics above show uncertainty, so does the line “i hope that’s true” at the end.

I caught you lookin’ at me in the 7-Eleven
 Under fluorescent lights

The reference to fluorescent lights might be significant in that they are often associated with harsh and unflattering lighting that can highlight flaws or make people feel exposed.

This could add to the sense of vulnerability or self-consciousness that the speaker may be feeling, as they describe being caught off guard by someone’s gaze.

There might’ve been a moment of unexpected connection or tension between the two people in this mundane, everyday setting.
And thought about kissing you underneath kitchen lights

This might be a reference to the beginning of “reckless driving”:

I didn’t mean to kiss you
I mean I did, but I didn’t think it’d go this far

The relationship that starts in this song might be the same that brutally ends on the next track.

I can see it now
 The wedding of the year
 I can see it now
 He stands up there and wipes his tears
 I can see it now
 When all my ghosts disappear
 I can see it crystal clear

This might be a reference to the bridge of the album opener “doomsday:” “And the funny thing is I would’ve married you / If you’d have stuck around / I feel more free than I have in years / six feet in the ground.” If the two tracks are about the same person, she might be describing her same dream wedding. She doesn’t have to be six feet in the ground if all her ghosts have disappeared.

Oh, all my ghosts are with me
 I know you feel them too

the “ghosts” are her past relationships or the memories of them haunting her in her current relationships. This line also insinuates that the “ghost” of her past relationships are affecting her current relationship with the line “I know you feel them too”

All my ghosts are with me
 I know you feel them too

the “ghosts” are her past relationships or the memories of them haunting her in her current relationships. This line also insinuates that the “ghost” of her past relationships are affecting her current relationship with the line “I know you feel them too”
You got a Slurpee for free
Every year on July 11th, 7-11 stores offer free Slurpees, but in 2021 you could get a free Slurpee any day in July.

description.plain: “called you again” is the fourth track on Lizzy McAlpine’s second album. The song talks about a relationship that’s ended, yet never seems to completely come to a close. The singer talks about not knowing when to let things go, resulting in seemingly only causing the other person pain. They’re over, they’re not friends anymore, they’re not dating anymore, but she can’t stop calling them and trying to maintain contact.

translation_songs.title: Lizzy McAlpine - called you again (Traducción al Español)

annotations:
And I should be the end of it
 But I never know when to stop talking

“You’ve made your bed, now lie in it,” is a common phrase used to tell someone to deal with the consequence(s) of their actions.

Lizzy is using this phrase with slightly different words and adds “alone” at the end, showing that while she was using the phrase as a metaphor, it was also literal: she actually sleeps in her bed alone.

She uses the next line to elaborate on the situation, saying she “never know[s] when [they’re] done talking,” likely meaning that she doesn’t know if she is allowed to be in a relationship with other people or if she is still in a committed relationship with this person.

The fact that she doesn’t know when they’re “done talking” indicates that there is a lack of communication now, she’s never even aware of where they stand, affecting whether she knows it’s okay to begin a relationship with someone else, or sleep with them.
’Cause I called you again

The song begins and ends with her calling the object of the song again. This (along with the way that all the verses begin with this same line after smooth transitions from the chorus) emphasizes the unhealthy cycle that she is stuck in, and that she will continue even after the song.
Did I call you again?
This line carries over from the end of the chorus, but it can also be taken as a standalone question where she is playing coy, or perhaps hanging on to some glimmer of hope.
